title: Tuesday, 24th January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
PM11:02am

Morning

PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:03am

Where some parts of said market are a little stressed this morning

PM11:03am

PM11:03am

Let's have Bernie

PM11:03am

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Ya reckon this really is the end?

PM11:05am

Most tedious thing on the box, to my mind

undefined
PM11:06am

We're not going to do lots on the Brexit judgement

11:06 am
PM11:06am

PM11:06am

Just mention that the krona again showing krona tendencies over the last few mins

PM11:06am

1.2441 on my screen

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Well, let's not overplay the sterling reaction. Here it is in graph form.

BE11:07am

PM11:07am

Yeah, a wobble

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Pretty absurd of the government to even try this royal prerogative gambit

BE11:08am

One can argue that. From the trading perspective, the upshot here is that the ruling changes nothing much because May had already committed to a Commons vote.

PM11:09am

Yep

11:09 am
BE11:09am

The only thing that changes is with regards to the local parliaments. So, if anything, we have one potential hurdle fewer.

BE11:09am

(Local isn't the right word. You know what I mean. Devolved. Whatever.)

PM11:09am

I do

11:10 am
BE11:10am

So let's ignore that entirely and get onto the warnings.

undefined
PM11:10am

Yeah!

11:10 am
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 315.00, down 67.56 (-17.66%), High: 330.00, Low: 308.55, Volume: 95.83m
PM11:10am

TinhatScorchedfingersTinhatScorchedfingers

PM11:11am

This is BT

11:10 am
PM11:11am

Not some volatile penny dreadful

PM11:11am

Must be one of the most widely owned stocks in Britain

BE11:11am

It's a multi headed warning here. A hydra.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Losing all control of the Italy side is bad, clearly. And very expensive.

BE11:11am

But it's also a profit warning on public sector spending

BE11:12am

And a very gloomy outlook for the dull, domestic, utility like core.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Question #1: can BT now afford its dividend? Maybe not.

PM11:12am

Ouch

PM11:12am

Really??

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Question #2: Why on earth is it chucking cash up the wall on football rights with an unsustainable ARPU structure when it might not be able to afford its dividend?

BE11:13am

I don't know the answer to that one.

PM11:13am

hehehehehe

11:13 am
PM11:13am

It's a fair question, even if you can't answer

PM11:14am

The football move looks absurd with hindsight

PM11:14am

Utterly absurd

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Can't help be think that this public sector warning tho will be haunting a lot of other companies as well.

PM11:15am

Brexit paralysis

BE11:15am

We don't usually give Louis Capital a huge amount of airtime here, but Saeed Baradar has long been a very aggressive seller BT and is quite happy this morning.

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Go, what's he saying in celebration?

BE11:16am

**** A GOOD DAY TO TRY TO PUT ALL THE BAD NEWS OUT BUT IT IS NOT EASY TO HIDE THE FACTS - While all the headlines this morning concentrated on the problems in Italy and the multi-year accounting irregularities, the company pushed out an even more important development - the UK PROFIT WARNING AND WEAKNESS ACROSS THE BOARD in international markets.

**** BT CONFIRMS A SLOWDOWN IN THE UK AND CONFIRMS NO PICK UP IN PUBLIC-SECTOR CONTRACTS IN CONTRAST TO PREVIOUS Q4's - The company also confirms that they are seeing weaker pipeline for business in the UK, that budgets are being squeezed due to Brexit and that public sector contracts are ending sooner than expected. However the profit warning is not restricted to the UK business only.

BE11:16am

**** THIS IS A PROFIT WARNING ACROSS THE BOARD - BT confirms that they are seeing similar pressure in the international corporate market. This does not bode well for the "Global Services" division which was recovering and implies pressures across the board and across divisions. As such today's event is not really concentrated in Italy - Italy is just a small sideshow in a business which is under pressure all over.

**** NEXT EVENT : I EXPECT TO SEE AN ADJUSTMENT DOWNWARDS IN DIVIDEND EXPECTATIONS. The weakening fundamental health of this company is not in line with a 10%pa dividend increase policy. Watch this space - a cut in dividend or at best a flat dividend will be the next major newsflow.

11:16 am
PM11:16am

He's a bit shouty

BE11:16am

**** THE MAIN FUNDAMENTAL RISK IS STILL TO MATERIALIZE : INVESTMENTS IN CONTENT CANNOT BE JUSTIFIED and will lead to earning dilution and a decrease in Return in Capital Employed (ROCE) and this will become more visible with the upcoming auction of the European Champions League in 2017. I calculate the breakeven point of a BT TV sports customer at nearly £32/month. They will never recoup that cost and hence this is purely a very expensive retention tool which will fail and lead to earning dilution. The fact that BT has now started to charge nominal prices between £3.5-£7.5/month for BT sports does not change the facts that they are still 5-10x away from break even point.

**** TRADING STRATEGY : STOCK CLOSING ON MY PT OF 300p. However, the fundamentals have now changed and hence I have to look at my valuation models again. Under no circumstances will I be a BUYER of the stock at these levels as any dead cat bounce over the next few sessions will be short-lived. Numbers have to come down and with 15 BUYS and only 3 SELLS the analyst community is still to turn. The majority still hold the wrong conclusion that investment in content is beneficial for BT, so we still need to see the BULLS turn before we even get close to a BUYING opportunity.

BE11:16am

Yes, he is. Which I'd argue is to his credit.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

If you want a quieter, "we are adjusting out expectations downwards and anticipate some selling pressure on the stock this morning" type comment, I have lots of that too.

PM11:17am

How about someone who is rather unhappy this morning

PM11:17am

Such as John Karidis at Haitong

11:17 am
PM11:18am

BT Group / BT/A LN - Bitter disappointment, but stock has overreacted

Under review

PM11:18am

It's quite painful to read this

PM11:18am

Today BT [BT/A LN, 313p*, Under Review] warned about (i) BT Italy and (ii) the outlook for UK public sector and international corporate markets, which is a bitter disappointment to us. More so because, we think, these two issues are far from the most consequential drivers of BT’s share price at current levels: we think regulation and the pension deficit remain much more important determinants of BT’s net present value.

During the call, BT said that prospects for the rest of the group (c.80% of total EBITDA-capex) remain good, but management should have brought forward 3Q FY17 results (out this Friday) to talk much more expansively about this. Not doing so, we think, was a mistake.

Based on our experience of BT and our work on the company to date, we think management has chosen to reflect the causes of today’s profit warning onto revised FY17 and FY18 guidance, but not the continuing good performance of other BT divisions (e.g. BT Consumer, EE and Openreach). As ever, BT always errs heavily on the side of caution.

We think this also because, despite today’s profit warning, BT has not changed dividend guidance of ‘at least 10% growth’ in FY17 and again in FY18.

We need BT to report full 3Q FY17 results this Friday before we settle on our new numbers, fair value and hence recommendation. Therefore we place both under review until then.

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Will leave it there

BE11:19am

The thing with BT is that it should be boring.

BE11:19am

Finding out that one division has been cooking its numbers (do I need to throw in an allegedly there? I don't think I do) is unfortunate.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Having the public sector deteriorate is slightly less unfortunate, given it's been a cyclical trend for Enterprise for as long as it's existed.

BE11:20am

What's not unfortunate is having a business model that's no longer boring enough to absorb this stuff.

BE11:21am

Have Morgan Stanley.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

The Italian unit contributes to only 1% of Group EBITDA. The
UK public sector and international corporate markets make up more, but still quite small in the context of the Group at less than 10% (MS estimate). On a headline basis, we estimate that the new guidance implies a 3-5% downgrade to consensus EBITDA and 12-21% downgrade on free cash flow. Stripping out the impact of Italy, the underlying downgrade is 1-2% on EBITDA and 6-7% on free cash flow. The FCF impact is larger than EBITDA due to negative working capital. This is associated with timings of cash flow in the public sector and international markets.

BE11:21am

What's the current valuation? The shares have fallen -18% on the news (to 315p), taking them down more than the underlying downgrade. For March 2018, the company targets £3.0-3.1bn of normalised cash flow, which after pension payments and restructuring, amounts to around £2.1bn. This equates to a FCFE yield of c6.5% vs the sector at 7.9%. The company has reaffirmed its dividend commitment of at least a 10% YoY increase. Dividend coverage looks reasonable still. The company targets payments of c£1.7bn for FY18 – still below the cash generation above. On our estimates, the dividend yield of BT is 5.5% vs 4.9% for the sector in FY18.

BE11:22am

What is going right: Unexpectedly, the call was dominated by bearish questions surrounding Brexit and corporate spending, and we think it will take time for BT to regain investor confidence over accounting issues. However, not all was bad news given positive trends in the consumer segment (c30% of EBITDA). The press release mentions that BT is also expecting positive revenue growth at EE (for the first time) and fibre connections to reach new highs this quarter. This is consistent with our AlphaWise survey data, which indicated further strong quarters ahead for BT with market share wins in broadband and TV and rising
ARPU. BT also announced Consumer price increases last week, which will come into effect in April. It is worth noting that the last price rises came in July 2016, so the quarter ended June (fiscal Q1 2018) should see a positive impact from “double” Consumer price rises.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

The sound you can hear is straws being clutched.

undefined
BE11:23am

@Dub, on Actelion .... dunno.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Lots of the warmer types of punters buying yesterday in anticipation of news in the very short term.

BE11:24am

But we've no idea if they're right to expect that. Sorry.

undefined
11:24 am
PM11:24am

Next up -- easyjet

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 996.00, down 80 (-7.43%), High: 1,018, Low: 979.00, Volume: 7.03m
BE11:24am

Usual stuff.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

TinhatScorchedfingersTinhatScorchedfingers

BE11:25am

FX and fuel undermining what little progress there is operationally

BE11:25am

2017 is basically a warning. Consensus falls by about 10% I think.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Revenue per seat still quite poor, and worse than expected.

PM11:26am

Remember this stock has halved over the past two years

PM11:27am

Hit a low of 882 last October

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Yep. Pre results there was a push by several brokers -- Merrill most notably I think -- to argue that expectations had been reset to a level that they were effectively lowballed.

BE11:27am

Turns out, not so much.

BE11:28am

Here's SocGen. Sellers.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Actually, not SocGen because it's a pain to cut and paste. Here's Deutsche. Holders.

BE11:29am

We think easyJet’s Q1-17 IMS for the year ending September 2017 is slightly weak. Management has not issued any earnings guidance, but in our view revenue trends appear slightly weaker, costs are in-line (but high) and Fuel/FX are slightly worse. For FY17 consensus (Reuters) PBT is £413m, DBE £416m. We would expect low single digit percentage cuts to consensus following this IMS.

BE11:29am

Q1-17 revenue per seat at constant currency has fallen 8.2% which is slightly better than management’s previous indication of -8.7%. However for the H1-17 period, revenue per seat (cc) guidance has been reduced from a "mid to high single digit decline" to "high single digits" - a small downgrade. Management has cited (i) Easter moving entirely into H2 and (ii) some H1 impact from the Berlin attack as being causes. Adjusting for these, on an "underlying" basis management has indicated that there is a positive trend into Q2 which is continuing into Q3. We suspect the market will not look much beyond the headline small downgrade to revenue per seat guidance.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

FX is now expected to have a £75m/£105m negative impact in H1/FY versus previous guidance of £70m/£90m. The unit fuel bill is also now expected to decline between £215m-£240m versus previous guidance of £245m-£275m. Both moves are not surprising given the movement of exchange rates (particularly sterling) and jet fuel. Nevertheless the scale of the change to the full year mid-points (£15m on FX and £32.5m on Fuel) suggests downside to consensus albeit this is not in management’s control.

BE11:30am

Guidance on cost and capacity has been maintained. On cost, Q1-17 cost per seat ex-fuel (cc) increased +1.1% which is consistent with reiterated guidance for the full year of +1%. Nevertheless in our view this unit cost guidance is already too high given that management is still expecting to grow full year capacity by up to +9%.

BE11:30am

In the short-term we believe the slightly weaker revenue guidance, FX & Fuel will probably lead to small consensus cuts. In the medium-term it is all about whether easyJet can arrest its weakening revenue trends (and there are some small positive signs here, albeit "underlying") and whether it can demonstrate strong cost control (not really clear at this stage in our view). Whilst we believe easyJet can readily raise financing through numerous channels, we are also cautious on operating cash flow not covering expected gross capex over the next few years. On our existing numbers, we see easyJet trading on 10.4x 2017 PE and 6.5x EV/EBITDAR.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Now ......

BE11:31am

It seems necessary to remind that, as per its annual report in December, EasyJet cut Carolyn McCall's full bonus payout trigger

BE11:31am

It's now down to a 13% return on return, from 20% previously.

11:31 am
PM11:31am

So she wasn't poached

PM11:31am

ha. ha.

BE11:31am

That's the one.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

A reminder also that last year Carolyn earned £704k and £189k bonus, £518k in stock awards and £49k into the pension.

BE11:31am

So, £1.5m

BE11:32am

Which, to be clear, was a considerable pay cut!

11:31 am
BE11:32am

In 2015 she took home £6.2m

BE11:32am

2014: £9.2m

BE11:32am

2013: £7.8m

11:32 am
BE11:32am

2012: £3.7m

PM11:32am

Censored

BE11:32am

I make that about £28.5m in five years.

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Staggering, really

BE11:33am

A reminder also of that EasyJet vs Ryanair graph, normalised at 100 from when McCall started in 2010.

BE11:33am

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Now I don't have figures for Michael O'Leary that are directly comparable.

BE11:33am

He's paid in euros, for one thing.

BE11:33am

And Ryanais only discloses a salary + cash bonus, no other benefits.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Their disclosure's been the subject of criticism from Pirc.

BE11:33am

But as a guide, at the current euro-to-sterling rate ....

BE11:34am

.... I make it that O'Leary took home about £7.4m over five years to end March 2015.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

(And remember that, every single AGM, a fifth of Ryanair shareholders vote against remuneration.)

BE11:34am

The upshot here is that McCall's earned nearly four times more than O'Leary over the past half decade.

BE11:34am

And EasyJet stock is up approximately half as much as Ryanair's in McCall's tenure.

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Yeah, sorry, a tad late

PM11:35am

Staggering

undefined
11:35 am
PM11:35am

Why's Cussons at the top of the 250 fallers?

PM11:35am

PZ Cussons

BE11:36am

Haven't looked closely. Nigerian soap didn't catch my attention this morning, sadly.

11:36 am
PM11:36am

Liquidity in Nigeria remains poor with the exchange rate continuing to weaken on both interbank and secondary markets

PM11:36am

Maybe it should have done

BE11:37am

Guidance sticks but H1 slightly poor, loads to do in the second half, seems to be the theme here.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Here's Shore to summarise.

BE11:37am

PZ Cussons has printed subdued results for the 30th November 2016 which in our view represent a modest miss to management’s previous guidance for ‘broadly flat’ profits yoy. CPTP is reported at £40.2m which compares with the £42.1m in H1 FY2016, down 5.5% on an constant currency basis. Group EBIT fell 8.4% to £41.8m (from £45.2m), with the margin down 60bp to 11.1% on 2.6% constant currency sales decline. The group has also reported adjusted EPS of 6.50p which is down 10.7% yoy (note higher minorities), though with a long track record of growth a 2.3% increase in the interim dividend to 2.67p is proposed. Net debt was flat yoy at £191.3m.

BE11:37am

Looking across the group’s operating regions, we highlight:

· Africa - Operations remain under pressure from the economic challenges in key market Nigeria, the material devaluation of the Nigerian Naira and very tight liquidity within the country. Sales are reported to have fallen 14%, though on a constant currency basis sales nudged up 0.4% which is a commendable performance in our view. Divisional EBIT was robust increasing by £1.0m yoy to £11.6m, reported as a 29.9% improvement yoy on a constant currency basis

· Europe - Robust trading in the UK washing and bathing has been confirmed, though a poor summer for the Beauty division has resulted in constant currency sales down 6.3% to £134.6m and EBIT broadly flat at £26.5m (from £26.8m). UK growth continues to be driven by NPD in the UK whilst trading in Beauty has been good outside of the summer period when weather impacted St Tropez sales.

· Asia – Sales increased 18.2% on an actual basis through fell 1.4% on a constant currency a constant currency basis. However, the profit performance is very disappointing with divisional EBIT down c60% on a constant currency basis to £3.7m (from £7.8m). ‘Good’ growth in Indonesia more than offset by ‘tough’ trading environment in Australia where greater promotional spend has been required.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Whilst today’s update is a little disappointing, we do not at this stage anticipate changing our below consensus expectations, looking for CPTP of £99.6m, EPS of 16.9p. PZ Cussons is a company we like on a long term basis, with a high quality management team and market positions in key emerging markets (Nigeria and Indonesia) that we expect to be a major virtue on a five to ten year view. However, in the short term uncertainty around Nigeria (and increasingly Australia) remains a considerable constraint in our view with visibility on the former has little improved over the past 6 months and the latter deteriorating. Trading on a FY2017 PER of 19.9x and an EV/EBITDA multiple, we can understand why the valuation could tempt long term investors looking for exposure to the personal care category, however with concerns the stock could go down someway before achieving its long term potential we reiterate our HOLD stance.

BE11:38am

And I think that's all we have there.

undefined
11:38 am
BE11:38am

William Hill mentioned earlier.

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 263.80, down 13 (-4.70%), High: 272.00, Low: 263.60, Volume: 1.83m
BE11:39am

UBS has one of its Evidence Lab thingmies out.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Says Hill's still bleeding market share.

PM11:39am

Particularly online, i suspect

BE11:40am

I'm also wondering if this might be something to do with whether all William Hills have huge notices in the window to tell people not to gamble.

11:40 am
PM11:40am

hehehe

BE11:41am

I'm thinking it might work a bit like cigarette warnings. As in, there's a certain type of male smoker who buys the packet that warns about fetal damage rather than lung cancer.

BE11:42am

In the same way, if William Hill keeps reminding you about problem gambling you can either stop gambling or go down to Paddy Power, which doesn't.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

Just glancing at the UBS evidence lab thingy -- i note that they've been tracking app store downloads

PM11:42am

This seems a very obvious -- and smart -- thing to do

PM11:42am

Didn't realise the data was public

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Let me share what we have.

BE11:43am

The latest UBS Evidence lab data which tracks iOS app downloads for the top 30 sports betting apps in the UK shows that for WMH share of app downloads has decreased from 22% in H1'14 to just 10% in H2'16. We see no signs of WMH reversing this trend in the near term. We forecast WMH to deliver just 8% Online EBIT growth (CAGR 17-20e) compared to LCL of c20% before synergies, driving our view that WMH's Online business should be valued on a lower multiple. In separate notes published today we downgrade William Hill to Sell (new PT 240p) and maintain our preference for Ladbrokes Coral (Buy, new PT 160p).

BE11:43am

While William Hill has lost share of downloads over the past 2-3 years, Ladbrokes and SkyBet have gained the most share. We think SkyBet's impressive growth could be one reason for William Hill's weaker performance given both companies' strong football betting focus. Ladbrokes is showing stabilisation around 13% share of downloads, up from 5% in late 2014. We believe meaningful share shifts in digital downloads should translate to shifts in the underlying business in the medium, and hence await more encouraging data for WMH downloads before considering turning more positive.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

We believe the market is pricing in a scenario for LCL where FOBT maximum stakes are reduced to £10-15. For WMH however, we think the market incorrectly prices in no risk to Retail forecasts. Our detailed analysis of different regulatory scenarios outlines the potential downside to Retail forecasts. We see an average of -40% downside to Retail EBIT forecasts under the various scenarios. While we do not change our base case FOBT assumptions for either company, we now reduce the EBITDA multiple in our SOTP valuations by this 40% for both companies (from 8x to 5x) to reflect this risk.

BE11:43am

With increasing regulation/volatility of sports results, we believe it prudent to have a neutral exposure to the sector with a clear preference for LCL (Buy, PT 160p). LCL offers higher growth – we forecast an EPS CAGR (17-20e) of 13%, with the potential for. upgrades from higher than expected synergies, while for WMH we forecast an EPS CAGR of 11%. We see LCL as having more regulatory risk priced in, while the WMH shares fail to reflect this risk, and our data suggests WMH Online will not show a significant recovery in the near term.

BE11:43am

With regards FOBT .......

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Potential downside to 2018e EBIT forecasts from the regulatory review into Fixed Odds Betting Terminals (FOBTs) is significant, and we do not think this is reflected in the current share price. This compares to Ladbrokes Coral where we believe significant risk is already priced in. Our detailed analysis of different regulatory scenarios outlines the potential downside to machine gross win, Retail EBIT, and Group EBIT. We see an average of -40% downside to Retail EBIT forecasts under the various scenarios. While we do not change our base case FOBT assumptions we now adjust the EBITDA multiple in our SOTP valuation by this 40%, from 8x to 5x, to reflect the risk. We expect an update/more clarity on the regulation towards the end of Q1/early Q2.

undefined
PM11:44am

So much damage this morning -- that's not showing up in the Footsie

11:44 am
PM11:44am

(which is up 12 points)

PM11:44am

Dixons for example

Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 318.80, down 17.3 (-5.15%), High: 344.70, Low: 317.50, Volume: 4.81m
11:45 am
PM11:45am

I thought the Xmas statement was relatively ok -- clearly not

PM11:45am

http://www.investe...1701240700099001U/

BE11:46am

Dixphone had a bit of a run on the Sainsbury numbers (based on Argos doing okay) I think.

11:46 am
PM11:46am

Hmm

PM11:46am

Goodbody also thought the statement was ok

PM11:47am

As a marker in terms of retail demand for technology in the UK and Ireland Dixons Carphone
released a Trading Update this morning for the Christmas period. Like-for-like sales growth
for the Group as a whole was +4% with the UK and Ireland the driver of that growth (+6%
on a like-for-like basis). While indicating that they had outperformed the market over the
Christmas period the statement cited new technologies as a factor in demand, leading
management at Dixons Carphone to reiterate consensus PBT estimates in the range of
£475m - £495m for the year to April.

11:47 am
PM11:48am

Canaccord also buyers

PM11:48am

Given the H2 profit weighting, typically accounting for around 70% of the full year figure, the trading performance over this peak period was always going to be important, both regarding the FY17 outturn and investor sentiment. In the event, strong LFL trading, despite being held back by "patchy availability" of larger and higher margin phones and tablets, including Apple where the group overindexes, and a maintained group gross margin should offer some comfort on both fronts. We expect the balance of the strong LFL performance and PBT guidance to be a small net positive from a market perspective.

PM11:48am

The shares are trading on a cal 17E PER of 10.2x, with an EV/EBITDA of 6.0x. This puts the shares on almost a 25% discount to Hardlines peers and the wider sector, driven by concerns on the outlook for discretionary consumer expenditure and the impact of weaker sterling on prices and/or margins. Our TP is based on a 5% premium to the cal 17E sector PER rating.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Okay, so Geoff Ruddell at Morgan Stanley says the figures aren't as good as they look and there's nothing on strategy.

PM11:48am

ok, this sounds more instructive

BE11:49am

Yeah, he's usually the chap to listen to here.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

For what it's worth, I'm still slightly at a loss to know what Carphone is supposed to fill its huge stores with. They seem barren these days. Nothing in them at all.

BE11:50am

Here's MOST.

BE11:50am

- Given the importance of trading over the festive season to the full year outcome for Dixons Carphone, investors' principal focus today is likely to be the group LfL figure of 4% (vs consensus of 2.5%).
- This group figure, however, has been boosted by a strong headline LfL of 6% in the UK (vs a consensus expectation of +3.5%). Although this sounds very good, we think it important to remember that the group has been closing space and that the UK LfL has been boosted by 4% as a result of sales transferred from closing stores. Total sales in the UK were up only 3% (less than Argos, which reported 4% sales growth over Christmas and cited consumer electronics as an area of particular strength).
- There may also be some concern this morning about the -1% LfL reported in the Nordics. The market was anticipating a fairly weak figure there (consensus was looking for only +1%), but this is the first time in several years that we can recall LfL in this business falling into negative territory.

11:50 am
BE11:51am

- Although we were expecting the company to provide a strategy update this morning (having understandably chosen not to issue one with its Interims just before Christmas), there appears to be no 'n ew news' on such topics in this relatively short statement.
- We have yet to speak to the company this morning, but the statement makes clear that management is comfortable with a Headline Pre Tax Profit range for FY 2016/17 of £475m-£495m. According to Bloomberg consensus is currently looking for a figure of £487m (giving 30.9p of EPS), so we would not expect much change in consensus forecasts today.

undefined

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Company production guidance for 2017 is set at 35-43,000bpd which puts JEFe 42,270kbpd at the upper end of the range but means consensus will move down from its 51,600kbpd level. Mid-point of GENL's 2017 guidance would be -27% y/y from the 53,300bpd average Group production reported for 2016 (which itself was -37% y/y from 84,900bpd ave. Group production in 2015).

BE11:56am

Note the size of this Taq Taq cut.

BE11:56am

GENL's 2016 net production was split 50:50 between Taq Taq (GENL 44% WI of 60,100kbpd gross production) and Tawke (GENL 25% Wi of 107,300kbpd gross production). But new 2017 guidance emphasizes the differing fortunes of the fields as Taq Taq is expected to average 24-31,000bpd in 2017 (-54% y/y at the mid point!) whereas Tawke "is expected to remain stable at the current (Jan 2017) rate of 115,000bpd (+7% y/y from107.3kbpd gross in 2016).

11:56 am
BE11:56am

... and the degree to which Genel's boxed in here.

BE11:56am

Firm 2017 Taq Taq work program includes only one workover and one new appraisal well in the north of the field with further work contingent on "regular & predictable" KRG payments and partner approval. An updated Field Development Plan and CPR for Taq Taq are both "on track for completion in 1Q17". It is virtually certain, in our view, that this CPR will result in a further downgrade of "Estimated Ultimate Recovery (EUR) at the Taq Taq field from the 356mmb gross 2P reserves estimated on 29 Feb 2016, which was a 48% reduction from 683mmb previously. The stability of production at Tawke is therefore the most important positive factor in a GENL investment case. Tawke will also see further production support drilling/workover in 2017 as well as appraisal of the adjacent Peshkabir discovery is ongoing and with it the possibility of early production via Tawke facilities.

BE11:56am

Capex of $61m in 2016 is forecast to rise to $100 - 125m overall in 2017 of which $50 - 75m is for Taq Taq & Tawke, $10m is for KRI gas business (Miran/Bina Bawi) and $40m is for African exploration (of which $30m is future Morocco exploration commitment and we note GENL is in discussions with over the nature, scope & timing of this activity).

11:56 am
BE11:57am

What's next? Well ..........

BE11:57am

Net Debt of $240m at 31 Dec 2016 is slightly ahead of our $227m estimate and made up of $408m unrestricted cash balances and ~$650m bond (7.5% coupon, due May 2019). With all the issues GENL faces it is a relative positive that net debt is flat on $239m reported at 31 Dec 2015. Considering our production estimate for 2017 is inline and assuming Genel are able to defer most of that $30m Morroco exploration commitment we would expect the company to cover its costs in 2017 and even generate FCF of $20-30m.

BE11:57am

The KRI gas assets of Miran (75% WI) and Bina Bawi (80% WI) are expected to record a material impairment in 2016 accounts from the current $1.427bn carrying value (this in addition to the $198m carrying value impairment of the separate Chia Surkh asset already guided to). Efforts are continuing to farm-down the Miran/Bina Bawi licenses but with "firm 2017 activity expected to be largely technical and commercial in nature" the project continues to be stalled (and remains outside our PT) without a farm-in partner able to truly move the project further.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

BMO figures:

BE12:03pm

The price implies 2017, 2018, and 2019 EV/EBITDA multiples of 3.4x, 5.3x, and 10.1x (three- year average: 6.3x), a premium to RIO's 2017 EV/EBITDA of 4.4x.

BE12:03pm

• We attributed an NPV10% of US$650M for the mining operations (excluding supporting infrastructure such as the port), so on our numbers, the transaction appears accretive. From an EV/EBITDA perspective, and given our commodity price forecasts, we estimate 2017, 2018, and 2019 EV/EBITDA multiples of 3.4x, 5.3x, and 10.1x (6.3x for the three-year average), which represents a premium to Rio Tinto’s 2017 EV/EBITDA multiple of 4.4x.
• The transaction brings total disposals since January 2013 to US$7.7B, continuing Rio Tinto's strategy of optimising its portfolio to focus on tier one assets. Rio Tinto's balance sheet remains amongst the strongest of its peers with a projected year-end 2016 net debt position of less than US$11B and a net debt/EBITDA of 0.8x.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

A strong end to the year sees Fever-Tree announce it will again exceed expectations. It expects to deliver over 70% revenue growth for the year just closed, which prompts us to lift FY16E PBT forecasts by 12%. We also modestly increase our percentage growth assumptions for FY17E which produces a similar 12% PBT upgrade. Our DCF based TP increases to 1300p and we reiterate our BUY recommendation.

Fever-Tree has released its FY16 trading update and indicates that it expects to exceed market expectations after a very strong close to the year.
After delivering 69% revenue growth in 1H16, Fever-Tree reports it expects 2H16 revenues to be ahead by 75%, to deliver FY sales of c £102.2m (+72% yoy) and c.9% higher than our previous forecast (£93.9m). A strong close to the year is typically favourable for margins as much of the marketing spend has been committed/spent by December, so more of the gross profit drops to EBITDA and our margin assumption increases from 33.8% to 34.8%. Our PBT forecast increases to £34.8m with EPS of 24.1p (prev £30.9m, EPS 21.3p).
This upgrade has been driven by a stronger Q4 performance in most regions and in both the on- and off-trade. However, the UK remains the stand out region with growth expected of 118%. Europe will see revenues advance by c39% and the USA by c55%. ROW is expected to be c88% ahead. There is some currency benefit in these numbers; we estimate £5-6m.
For FY17E, we make a small adjustment to the percentage growth assumption from 12% to 15% which suggests revenue of £117.6m vs our previous £105.2m (+12%). PBT increases from £32.5m (EPS 22.4p) to £36.5m (EPS 25.1p). We leave our FY18E growth assumption at 10%, but forecasts increase given the higher revenue base.
In the UK the group has seen the premium mixer space develop to achieve a higher share of the market than anticipated and at a faster rate. It sees plenty of global headroom to continue to grow in the medium term.
